content.body: basically, for domintro sections, it causes Bikeshed to output `-dev`-suffixed IDs in the same way as we do for the HTML spec
content.formatted_body: basically, for domintro sections, it causes Bikeshed to output -dev-suffixed IDs in the same way as we do for the HTML spec

content.body: however, unlike what we do for the HTML spec â€” which relies on hardcoding `subdfn` attributes (and which we anyway added for a different purpose, for preserving link targets in the developer version) â€” that Bikeshed patch doesnâ€™t require any new markup in the spec source; instead it does it solely based on the presence of a `class=domintro` ancestor
content.formatted_body: however, unlike what we do for the HTML spec â€” which relies on hardcoding subdfn attributes (and which we anyway added for a different purpose, for preserving link targets in the developer version) â€” that Bikeshed patch doesnâ€™t require any new markup in the spec source; instead it does it solely based on the presence of a class=domintro ancestor

content.body: if it were to turn out that doing it solely based on the presence of a `class=domintro` ancestor doesnâ€™t actually ensure stable `-dev` IDs for the stuff we want, then I guess we would need to add some hardcoded attributes in the spec sources â€” but from testing Iâ€™ve done thus far, it seems like itâ€™s not in fact going to be necessary to change the spec sources at all
content.formatted_body: if it were to turn out that doing it solely based on the presence of a class=domintro ancestor doesnâ€™t actually ensure stable -dev IDs for the stuff we want, then I guess we would need to add some hardcoded attributes in the spec sources â€” but from testing Iâ€™ve done thus far, it seems like itâ€™s not in fact going to be necessary to change the spec sources at all

content.body: does anyone know how the TextEncoder interface came to be so... java-y, instead of just like `TextEncoder.encode('string')`? I think that every single time I have ever constructed a TextEncoder or TextDecoder it has been to invoke a single method on the new instance and then discard i

content.body: bakkot I assume to mirror the decoder interface which is stateful because it is capable of streaming? It would be nice to have a static method on `TextEncoder` / `TextDecoder` for single use encoding...
content.formatted_body: bakkot I assume to mirror the decoder interface which is stateful because it is capable of streaming? It would be nice to have a static method on TextEncoder / TextDecoder for single use encoding...

content.body: bleh. the stream transformer usage is fundamentally pretty different, it seems a shame they were conflated in TextEncoder
ah well
+1 to a static method. A bit dangerous people will use a sequence of static method calls when they should use the stateful instance, but probably worth it on the balance.
I'll open a spec issue
https://github.com/whatwg/encoding/issues/267

> <@domenicdenicola:matrix.org> +1 to a static method. A bit dangerous people will use a sequence of static method calls when they should use the stateful instance, but probably worth it on the balance.

is the instance actually stateful in any way other than holding onto its options bag?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @domenicdenicola:matrix.org
+1 to a static method. A bit dangerous people will use a sequence of static method calls when they should use the stateful instance, but probably worth it on the balance.
is the instance actually stateful in any way other than holding onto its options bag?

No, `TextEncoder` doesn't have a streaming mode
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @domenicdenicola:matrix.org
Yes it can hold half of a surrogate pair
No, TextEncoder doesn't have a streaming mode

content.body: `TextDecoder` does keep the decoder state in streaming mode though
content.formatted_body: TextDecoder does keep the decoder state in streaming mode though

content.body: That's `TextDecoderStream`, right?
content.formatted_body: That's TextDecoderStream, right?

content.body: not actually `TextDecoder` itself?
content.formatted_body: not actually TextDecoder itself?

content.body: TextDecoder itself
See the stream option on .decode
content.formatted_body: See the stream option on .decode

content.body: The danger is people will think because it's safe with TextEncoder, it's safe with TextDecoder. Or they will just always use the static method with TextDecoder for one-shots (where it's OK) but then carry over that experience to use it for chunks of a larger byte stream (where it's not)
oh, right, I forgot the decoder is not the same as the encoder here
i.e. `let str = ""; while (hasBytes()) { str += TextDecoder.decode(getBytes()); }` is very bad.
content.formatted_body: i.e. let str = ""; while (hasBytes()) { str += TextDecoder.decode(getBytes()); } is very bad.

content.body:
```js
const decoder = new TextDecoder();
console.log(decoder.decode(new Uint8Array([0xC3]), {stream: true})); // ""
console.log(decoder.decode(new Uint8Array([0xA1])));  // "Ã¡"
```
content.formatted_body:
const decoder = new TextDecoder();
console.log(decoder.decode(new Uint8Array([0xC3]), {stream: true})); // ""
console.log(decoder.decode(new Uint8Array([0xA1])));  // "Ã¡"

content.body:
> <@domenicdenicola:matrix.org> The danger is people will think because it's safe with TextEncoder, it's safe with TextDecoder. Or they will just always use the static method with TextDecoder for one-shots (where it's OK) but then carry over that experience to use it for chunks of a larger byte stream (where it's not)

Feel like we already have this though as stream: true is not the default.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @domenicdenicola:matrix.org
The danger is people will think because it's safe with TextEncoder, it's safe with TextDecoder. Or they will just always use the static method with TextDecoder for one-shots (where it's OK) but then carry over that experience to use it for chunks of a larger byte stream (where it's not)
Feel like we already have this though as stream: true is not the default.

People should just use the whatwg stream variant anyway ðŸ™ƒ

manually feeding items to a stream is a bit annoying IIRC
but yeah does seem like using a stream for that case seems better than having a `stream` option
content.formatted_body: but yeah does seem like using a stream for that case seems better than having a stream option

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> manually feeding items to a stream is a bit annoying IIRC

TextDecoderStream is a TransformStream style API with a readable and writable, so should be as easy as `writable.write(chunk)`
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @bakkot:matrix.org
manually feeding items to a stream is a bit annoying IIRC
TextDecoderStream is a TransformStream style API with a readable and writable, so should be as easy as writable.write(chunk)

content.body: Or if you already have a ReadableStream (for example a fetch response body or Blob) you can just call .pipeThrough on it ðŸ™‚
content.formatted_body: Or if you already have a ReadableStream (for example a fetch response body or Blob) you can just call .pipeThrough on it ðŸ™‚
